utterances: Well, Governor Schwarzenegger and - they're actually both still doing the press conference and I just stepped away.
You know, they both thanked the firefighters, that is the critical thing.
They say that they're doing an excellent job, working hard hours in hard condition.
Governor Schwarzenegger also mentioned something that they're already - the fire hasn't even - isn't even close to being out, but they're already working on an environmental recovery plan.
Because Lake Tahoe here is such a beautiful area, it's so prized by so many people.
They're already beginning on working on plans to restore the areas that have been burned and prevent the lake from being damaged.
Now just yesterday, firefighters sounded pretty confident that the fire would soon be under control.
What happened?
Well, the winds kicked up and they kicked up sooner than they were expecting them to.
It caught an amber, the amber jumped into a tree, the tree crowned and caught fire and started spraying ambers all over the place.
And it jumped the line and suddenly they were evacuating 2,000 more people.
Again, today, they are very concerned that the winds are going to kick up.
In fact, the winds have started blowing here now.
And they're very concerned about several neighborhoods that are between the fire and the lake.
And they're afraid that the fire could actually jump some lines that they've built, again, that it could jump a freeway.
And there are some very high-priced homes just on the other side of that freeway.
Well, thus far, the fire has really affected locals, people who live here year-round, who work for the county or worked at the resorts, or people who are real, genuine residents who live here.
Vacation homes have also been affected.
And this neighborhood that they're now worried about, Tahoe Keys, is definitely heavy with vacation homes.
But, you know, just walking around this town and going to the grocery store and at the hotel, there are just so many people who are affected.
And everybody's talking to their neighbors and their friends and everybody has a story.
Some of them are heartbreaking.
Well, why are these homes, in particular, so vulnerable?
Well, South Lake Tahoe is a desirable place because it's in the middle of a national forest.
There are trees everywhere and brush.
And because of the national forest, you know, the trees aren't always cleared.
And so, basically, the trees that make it so appealing are also what's making it so dangerous.
And I think this has been a horrible drought year.
We have very little snow packs, something like 29 percent of normal.
And the fire is just able to move right on through.
So what's the outlook for containing this fire?
Well, they say that if they can make it through today, and that's a big if, and winds are supposed to get up to 40 miles per hour.
If they can make it through today, then they think by tomorrow, maybe by July 4th, it will be fully contained.
Okay.
Thanks, Tamara.
That's reporter Tamara Keith of member station KQED.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Michele Norris.
And now, the high price of oil and gas and what it means for schools.
With gas and diesel selling for nearly $3 a gallon, there are reports that school districts are cutting back on field trips and bus routes and even charging students for rides to sporting events.
Rising gas prices have produced a windfall for some districts, especially in states where the gas tax is earmarked for school spending.
But in Kennebec County, Maine, as in many school districts around the country, energy prices have administrators feeling uneasy.
Paul Knowles, the superintendent of School Administrative District 11, that's based in Gardiner, Maine.
Mr. Knowles joins us now.
So glad you're with us.
Thank you for having me.
First, tell us a little bit about your school district.
How large is it?
How many students do you serve?
Well in the state of Maine, it's what we consider to be a medium or large size district.
We have approximately 2,300 students.
But geographically, our buses travel very large distance to the surrounding communities.
And, again, most of the schools are centered in the Gardiner City area.
And gas prices, how much have they increased?
Well we're not sure yet.
The problem is we haven't been able to go out and secure a bid on gasoline or diesel prices.
We did secure a bid on fuel oil, which is our heating oil number two at $2.29.
And our electric prices have doubled.
So that overall has meant a 23, almost a 24% increase just this year.
Add to that what we don't know as far as gas and diesel prices and, you know, we're probably talking around $200,000 or more of an increase in a $20 million budget, which is significant.
Now I understand this year you're trying something new.
You've actually joined with other schools and cities in order to attract bids for heating oil and bus fuel.
Can you tell us a little bit about that plan?
Yeah.
We have a company called Maine Power Options that proposed that we go out as a consortium to try to secure fuel oil prices, which we did.
And, again, a large number of not only school systems, but private businesses and other organizations.
We're part of that consortium and that's how we secured the $2.29 for heating oil.
But nobody, again, bid on gasoline or diesel.
So you're paying I guess what they call pool prices right now?
That's right.
Right now it's around $2.80, I think, plus the freight that it cost to deliver to our fuel depot.
Since you haven't been able to lock in a contract, how worried are you as you watch those prices tick ever higher.
Well it's a concern.
And, obviously, we are finalizing our budget and, you know, it's purely speculation on our part how much money we need to put in the budget in order to pay for gasoline and diesel.
And, again, the market continues to be very volatile.
So it's problematic.
I mean it's a guessing game.
We feel that we put an amount of money in and we just hope that it's going to cover the cost of diesel and gasoline.
Across the country we're hearing stories about school systems either cutting out field trips altogether or reducing them.
Have you made those kinds of changes or are you looking to do that in the fall?
We haven't done that yet.
Obviously there's some givens.
I mean we have to heat buildings, we have to transport children to and from school, which, you know, trying not to impact the extra-curricular activities.
We are looking at ways to combine, for instance, athletic teams as they go to schools to compete.
Looking at field trips, again, some combination or, you know, are these really essential to learning?
You know those kind of things, nice to do, but is it really essential to the curriculum and what's going on in the classroom.
What's your worst-case scenario?
What level or what price do you enter into sort of an emergency situation?
Well, you know, again, it's so volatile.
I mean if we start talking four and five dollar fuel, then, you know, we're going to be in a situation that that's where we're going to have to really cut back on things.
Right now we've been able to maintain, but, you know, if it continues to go up and up and up, that's going to impact us in a large way.
We're prepared to have to make cuts during the year if we have to, but we're hoping we don't have to do that.
Paul Knowles, thanks so much for talking to us.
You're very welcome.
Appreciate your time.
Paul Knowles, the superintendent of School Administrative District 11 based in Gardiner, Maine.
From NPR News this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
The Indian Health Service launched Alaska's dental therapy program more than a year ago.
The federal agency allows the therapists to treat Alaska natives.
But the American Dental Association thinks they should be subject to state licensing laws like dentists.
Jim Toll is executive director of the Alaska Dental Society which signed on to the lawsuit and echoes the concerns of the ADA.
He says the therapists are practicing dentistry illegally.
When we learned that there were training people taking people with essentially only a high school education.
Sending them out of the country, and they were coming back and doing irreversible surgical procedures, we said wait.
That's not good and it's not safe.
There are no dental therapy training programs in the United States.
So Alaska's dental therapists study in New Zealand instead, where therapists have been working since the early 1920s.
Dental therapists practice in other countries too, like Canada and Australia.
But Alaska's therapists are the first to treat patients in the U.S.
There are currently eight working in rural Alaska with four more in training.
They're allowed to perform simple fillings and extractions.
But Jim Toll says even minor procedures can lead to serious complications.
I have yet to meet a dentist who would tell you that there's any such thing as a simple extraction until it's over.
Dentists are trained to deal with all of the anomalies once they get in there and start doing that, to recognize to know how to respond and compensate.
At a clinic in Bethel in western Alaska, 10 dentists serve a region the size of Washington State.
A little tiny sweep, and then brush down.
Most patients aren't on the road system so even a minor problem requires a long and expensive plane trip.
The Bethel Clinic is trying to entice six more dentists to join their team with compensation packages of almost $180,000 a year.
But the positions have been open for six years.
Dentist Mary Willard says therapists are beginning to fill the need.
We have a whole waiting room full of people with tooth aches basically and we tend to treat our patients on a as-need basis sometimes because we're so short of staff.
That's not really the most efficient way to do dentistry.
Kids in rural Alaska suffer from tooth decay at two-and-a-half times the national average.
Lillian Magilten (ph) is a dental therapist who just began practicing in Tuksuk Bay, a small village on the Baring Sea.
When I was in Christ's Church, the dental therapist, my host dental therapist, Esreket (ph).
She's like oh, look at all these bombed out teeth.
You know and I'd look over her shoulder and then they'd come up, and then you come back to Alaska and it's like, man, those bombed out teeth are nothing compared to what I'm seeing today.
The tribal organization that oversees the program is hopeful the therapists will win the right to continue practicing.
Legal Affairs Director Valerie Davidson says a lot is at stake.
I think it will be a significant loss.
Right now the dental health therapists are providing a service in many villages in which they have no other access to dental care.
The dentists aren't there.
For NPR News in Anchorage, I'm Annie Feidt.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Melissa Block.
